How VAT works
1. Overview
VAT (Value Added Tax) is a tax added to most products and services sold by
VAT-registered businesses.
Businesses have to register for VAT (/register-for-vat) if their VAT taxable
turnover is more than £90,000. They can also choose to register if their
turnover is less than £90,000.
This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg) (/sut-mae-taw-yn-
gweithio).
Your responsibilities as a VAT-registered business
As a VAT-registered business you must:

As a VAT-registered business you must:
include VAT in the price of all goods and services at the correct rate (/vat-
rates)
keep records (/charge-reclaim-record-vat/keeping-vat-records) of how much
VAT you pay for things you buy for your business
account for VAT on any goods you import into the UK 
report the amount of VAT you charged your customers and the amount of
VAT you paid to other businesses by sending a VAT return (/submit-vat-

- usually every 3 months
pay any VAT you owe to HMRC
The VAT you pay is usually the difference between any VAT you’ve paid to
other businesses, and the VAT you’ve charged your customers.
If you’ve charged more VAT than you’ve paid, you must pay the difference
to HMRC.
If you’ve paid more VAT than you’ve charged, HMRC will usually repay you
the difference (/vat-repayments).

You can appoint an agent to deal with HMRC on your behalf if you
prefer.
There are VAT schemes (/how-vat-works/vat-schemes) you can join that affect
how you calculate and report the VAT you owe HMRC.
2. What VAT is charged on
VAT is charged on things like:
goods and services (a service is anything other than supplying goods)
hiring or loaning goods to someone
selling business assets
commission
items sold to staff - for example canteen meals
business goods used for personal reasons

business goods used for personal reasons
‘non-sales’ like bartering, part-exchange (/guidance/vat-part-exchanges-
barters-and-set-offs) and gifts
These are known as ‘taxable supplies’. There are different rules for charities
(/vat-charities/registration).
VAT is not charged on goods or services that are exempt from VAT or are
unaffected by VAT (/charge-reclaim-record-vat/when-not-to-charge-vat) (‘out of
scope’).

3. How much VAT you must charge
There are 3 different rates of VAT (/vat-rates) that can be added to products.
Which one applies depends on the goods and services, and how they’re
used.
Most goods and services are charged at the standard rate of 20%. You
should charge this rate unless the goods or services are classed as reduced
or zero-rated.
Get a list of reduced or zero-rated goods and services (/guidance/rates-of-vat-
on-different-goods-and-services).

expect to).

5. VAT schemes
VAT schemes are designed to simplify the way some VAT-registered
businesses calculate and account for VAT to HMRC.
They do not change the amount of VAT businesses charge for their products
and services. They are voluntary to join.
VAT Flat Rate Scheme

text:
VAT Flat Rate Scheme
The VAT Flat Rate Scheme (/vat-flat-rate-scheme) lets you work out what you
owe HMRC in VAT as a percentage of your gross turnover.
You can only use this scheme if you’re a small business with an annual
taxable turnover of £150,000 or less excluding VAT.
The amount of VAT you pay depends on your industry and type of business.
Other VAT schemes

text:
There are other VAT schemes you may be able to join depending on your
VAT taxable turnover and type of business.
If your annual VAT taxable turnover is £1.35 million or less, you may be
eligible for the:
VAT Annual Accounting Scheme (/vat-annual-accounting-scheme) - complete
one VAT return each year instead of 4
VAT Cash Accounting Scheme (/vat-cash-accounting-scheme) - pay VAT to
HMRC when your customer pays you rather than when you invoice them

If you are a retail business or sell second-hand goods, you may be able to
use:
a VAT margin scheme (/vat-margin-schemes) - pay VAT on the value you
add to the goods you sell rather than on the full selling price of each item
one of 3 VAT retail schemes (/vat-retail-schemes) - calculate the VAT once
with each VAT return rather than calculating it for each sale you make
